instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A MacBook air that is not powering on and is exhibiting weird behavior on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> rail. With charger plugged in and motherboard out of computer I get fluctuating voltages on both pins of F7140. The fan initially begins spinning but dies again after a few seconds. Shortly after it will do this again in the same order, however it does not always begin this loop immediately, sometimes it takes several moments. On F7140, I get 8.87V max for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> which drops down to 5.32V, then up to 7.46V and back to 8.87V every times the fan starts spinning but the fan always stops spinning once PPBUS gets back to 8.87V. I also took some other measurements around the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> region.
I am getting the 5.1V on pin19 and 20 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, and 4.32V on <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> pin of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. I am showing 16.09V on pin 2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and there is no continuity to ground through that MOSFET so I do not think it is shorted to ground. I am also getting 8.87V on <SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL> and 0.54V on <SIGNAL>CHGR_LGATE</SIGNAL> of <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, which I thought was strange.

Thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: I suspect a rail is shorted and is pulling down PPBUS when the board tries to power on. Check all rails for shorts. Also check resistance between pin 17/18 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: I get 2.9 ohms between pins 17/18 and 20.5 ohms of resistance between pins 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. Will test for short on other rails when I get the chance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: Also try a charged battery and see if it powers from that. Green/orange light present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message:
With only battery and motherboard, I get 6.83V on <SIGNAL>PPBYS_G3H</SIGNAL> that jumps to 7.25V when charger is added. With both battery and charger PPBUS slowly rises from 7.25V to 7.63V and stabilizes.

Started going down the power rails, and am posting the measurements I have taken so far:

G3Hot is 3.39V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> is 8.56V that does not fluctuate with or without fan spin
 <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is 0V and then jumps to 0.38V when fan starts to spin
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.31 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 4.98V at pin 1 of L4820
0V at Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R1920</RESISTOR>
0V at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R8081</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 3.3V on pin 5 of <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>
3.3V is present on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R8187</RESISTOR> when fan is spinning

Will go back through and measure rails again tonight when I have much more time to work on this, but was wondering if anything from what I have posted so far looks abnormal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> is 8.56V is directly connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> so check your measurements. If <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is coming up then it means it is power cycling. Check PPBUS again if it stays at 8.6V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message:
I rechecked my measurements and realized that I was missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and it was at 0V. Since this rail comes from the dc-in board, I went ahead and replaced that as well but I seem to be having the same issue with this missing power rail as before. After replacing with new DC-in board I took some more measurements and they are as follows:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.56V but drops to 7.4V when the fan intermittently begins spinning, and then back up to 8.56V when the fan stops
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> is 0V, but jumps to 5.09V when the fan begins to spin, and then back to 0V when the fan stops. This was measured at pin 1 of L7520. The resistance to ground on this line is 55.6k ohms
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.39V at pin 2 of L7095 and stays present with or without fan spin
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 4.98V normally, and drops to 0V when the fan begins to spin (measured on pin 1 of L4820)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is 0V normally, but jumps to 5V when the fan begins to spin.

I also noticed that sometimes when the magsafe is plugged in I do not get any green or orange light, but <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other power rails measured above always hold the same values regardless of light being present or not.

So it is apparent that the board is trying to power on, but it can't and I think it has something to do with the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> power rail but I am stumped as to where to go next. With new DC-in board, my results are pretty much the same as before. Do you think this problem could be because of the 821-1721-A cable being bad that connects the I/O board to motherboard? I unfortunately do not have another for reference and would have to order one, but would like a second opinion before doing so. Cable looks fine physically.

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> should never drop to 0V. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> staying high?
I still need to know if any power rails are shorted to GND, check all coils for shorts to GND.
History of the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> tests at a solid 0.98V with or without the fan spin at pin 1 of RR8140
I rechecked <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and it stays at 4.98V with or without fan spin at pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7400</CAPACITOR>

According to customer, the device died one day and she has no longer been able to power it all of the way on, even though she is getting green/orange light on charger. She took it to apple and they told her it was either a bad battery or bad motherboard. We already confirmed that it is not a battery with a known-good battery. No signs of liquid damage or corrosion, board looks very clean. 

I will be testing each rail for a short to ground this evening and will post those results when I have them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: Found that there is 0V measured in Diode mode on both pins of L7310 and L7320, however all other inductors seem to measure a normal value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message:
Took a look at <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and there is 0V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUVR_VDD</SIGNAL> pin 16 that jumps to 5.12V when the fan begins spinning. Also noticed that CPU is warm with no fan spin, but when the fan starts spinning the VPU becomes so hot I can barely hold my finger on it.
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> is 0.8V on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> that falls to 0V without fan spin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: These CPUs should not get that hot. It should take a while before your finger burns. Measure resistance to GND on L7310, not diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message:
It kind of does take a while. So as mentioned, when the magsage is first connected, there is green/orange light and then after a few moments fan starts spinning for a few seconds then stops. And it will keep going with this loop. CPU initially gets warm, and as the fan goes into this loop is when the CPU starts getting very hot.

resistance to GND on both sides of L3170 is 0ohms. Same on L7320.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: You sure about 0 Ohm on L7310? This would indicate a shorted CPU.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: Yes. 0.3 ohms on L7310. That is unfortunate if that is the case. Does that explain why <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> is missing as well(not shorted to GND, just 0V)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> will be present and it will be pulsing. Must have been liquid in the CPU regulator area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: It is showing a steady 0V on every test point I could find for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>. And <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> area looks flawless of that is what you are referring to. Does not show any signs of liquid damage. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and enable are missing as well. Anything else I can do to find what the problem is being caused by?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message:
You said "Took a look at [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/d2-<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>.html"]<CHIP>U7200</CHIP>[/URL] and there is 0V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUVR_VDD</SIGNAL> pin 16 that jumps to 5.12V when the fan begins spinning."
That 5V comes from <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> which comes from <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>. But this is all time wasting as the CPU is shorted and this board is trash, RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on/wierd behavior
threads.message: Got it. The board operation seemed to be digressing as time went on, which is why some of my measurements changed. Now the CPU does not get warm and there is never any fan spin. But thank you for the help, it is a good donor board if nothing else....
